questions.skill: Explaining how figurative language impacts meaning.
questions.stimulus: (1) The Whispering Woods had always been a dare. (2) Leo, who thought he was brave as a lion, nudged me. (3) "Don't be a chicken, Maya," he grinned, but his smile was a flickering candle in the gloom. (4) I looked at the woods. (5) The trees stood like silent, skeletal guards at a forgotten gate. (6) Above us, a sliver of moon, pale as bone, peeked through the canopy. (7) We stepped inside, and the fog was a creeping gray blanket, instantly swallowing the path. (8) The wind whispered secrets through the high branches, and every fallen leaf seemed to hold its breath. (9) "I have a million butterflies in my stomach," I mumbled. (10) A twig snapped nearby. (11) Leo jumped, his bravado vanishing like smoke. (12) "What was that?" he hissed, his voice a dry leaf skittering on pavement. (13) "This place is an icebox," he shivered, though the night was mild. (14) We were prisoners of our own fear, rooted to the spot. (15) We both knew this was a bad idea; it was written all over Leo's face.
questions.stem: In sentence 2, the author uses the simile "brave as a lion" to describe Leo. What does this figurative language mean?
options: Leo is loud and likes to roar.
Leo is very courageous or acts like he is.
Leo has sharp claws and teeth.
Leo is the leader of the group.

questions.stem: In sentence 8, the author states, "The wind whispered secrets through the high branches." How does this use of personification impact the mood of the story?
options: It creates a joyful mood by suggesting the wind is playful.
It creates a mysterious and uneasy mood, as if the woods are alive and hiding things.
It creates a peaceful mood by describing the gentle sound of the wind.
It creates an angry mood, as if the wind is yelling at the children.
